creditline: Museum purchase, Fowler McCormick, Class of 1921, Fund
signed: Signed (2013-78 b): Chak Til Mo’ (‘Red Tapir-Macaw’)

texts.textentryhtml:
1950s, Robert L. Stolper, London [1]; by 1959, acquired by Jay C. Leff (1925-2000), Uniontown, PA [2]; Judith Nash, New York [3]; 1981, sold to Peter G. Wray (1934-2016), Scottsdale, AZ (no. 7080-W) [4]. Richard Manoogian, Detroit, IL [5]; November 19, 1990, Sotheby’s, New York, lot 91. 1991, US private collection; 2013, sold to the Princeton University Art Museum.

Notes:
[1] According to correspondence with Scott Leff, dated August 2, 2020, referring to Jay C. Leff’s ledger.
[2] According to the work’s inclusion in the exhibition Exotic Art from Ancient and Primitive Cultures, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, 1959.
[3] According to US private collection.
[4] According to US private collection and Sotheby’s, Pre-Columbian Art (New York: Sotheby’s, 1990), lot 91.
[5] Ibid.

These sculptures represent two distinct aspects of pawatuns—old male deities who are thought to support the world. One resides in a conch shell, while the other presents a hybrid creature combining fish fins and the hindquarters of a crocodile; a fish nibbles at the tip of the latter creature’s tail. Each is further embellished with brief hieroglyphic texts, including the name of the pair’s original owner: Til Man K’ihnich (Radiant Tapir?), sovereign of the “water-scroll” kingdom, probably in Belize. Another text tucked under the spiral of one pawatun’s conch shell is an extremely rare artist’s signature, stating that “Red Tapir Macaw was the sculptor.”

caption: Maya, Early Classic Period, Signed: Chak Til Mo’ (‘Red Tapir-Macaw’), ca. 550 CE, Maya area, Belize, Mesoamerica, Two pawatuns. White stone (fine-grained chalk); 13.3 x 17.1 x 14.6 cm (a), 12.7 x 13.3 x 17.8 cm (b). Museum purchase, Fowler McCormick, Class of 1921, Fund (2013-78 a-b)
